title: Style Guide
content: What developers need to know before they build a GFW apphttp://vizzuality.github.io/gfw-style-guides/

title: Carbon Loss API
content: Works similar to the forest change API.Currently only ARCGIS API, Wrapper under development.Not yet documented.

title: Land Cover API
content: Works similar to the forest change API.Currently only ARCGIS API, Wrapper under development.Not yet documented.

title: Forest Change by Landcover API
content: Works similar to the forest change API.Currently only ARCGIS API, Wrapper under development.Not yet documented.

title: Forest Change by Landcover API
content: Works similar to the forest change API.Currently only ARCGIS API, Wrapper under development.Not yet documented.

title: My Global Forest Watch API
content: Subscribe to GFW alerts and manage your subscriptions using this API. This will allow users to access their subscriptions through other apps.Under development.

title: Metadata API
content: http://api.globalforestwatch.org/metadataRetrieve full metadata for all GFW layers as JSON object. Soon also as XML object in ArcGIS, ISO and FGDC standard to use.(Not yet documented)

title: Forest Change API
content: http://api.globalforestwatch.org/forest-changeUsers can make calls to the GFW API and receive statistics on:	University of Maryland (UMD)/Google tree cover loss & gain	FORMA alerts	IMAZON SAD alerts	QUICC alerts	Terra-i alerts	NASA active firesThey can post their own geometry, or use predefined geometries such as administrative boundaries, concessions or protected areas.They can also specify the time period for they are interested in.Full documentation of the calls are herehttps://github.com/wri/gfw-api

title: Atlas 10
content: GFW aims to radically improve the availability, quality, and accessibility of forest data for everyone:  Governments can use GFW to detect illegal forest clearing and target forest law enforcement efforts.  Companies can monitor the impacts of commodity supply chains on forests and demonstrate compliance with sustainability commitments and certifications. Learn more at GFW Commodities.  NGOs & civil society can identify deforestation hotspots and bolster their investigations, advocacy, and campaigns.  Indigenous communities can monitor their territories and raise an alarm when their customary forests are threatened.  Media can gather evidence, data, and graphics for reporting.  Researchers can analyze forest trends on a local or global scale and better understand the causes of forest change.  Concerned citizens everywhere can learn more about the state of forests and participate in forest monitoring. Students and educators can learn more about forests at local and global scales.

title: Developer tools
content: Developer tools	        Do you ever wish that Global Forest Watch could be customized for your geography or a specific issue? Do you have a great idea for how GFW data could help solve a specific problem? Using GFW’s public Application Programming Interface (API) and open source code, anyone can build on GFW data and technology to create customized web-based or mobile applications. This section contains the tools and information you need to develop applications that harness Global Forest Watch data and technology.            Browse all Global Forest Watch apps here.

title: Gallery
content: Gallery    Check out our hand-picked selection of maps and apps from others in the GFW community. Look here for inspiration, or submit your map to be featured.  						You may find this interesting							  		  							  							Map builder				Build and share your own GFW map by choosing your own data, map style, and location.  					  		  	  	  		  											Developer tools				Use our open source code to create customized web-based or mobile applications using GFW data and tools.

title: Map Builder
content: Map Builder	  Want to create your own version of Global Forest Watch, featuring a specific location or type of data? Map Builder is an easy tool to help you build your own mapping portal, complete with powerful analytical tools.															Compelling data				Choose from dozens of data layers curated by Global Forest Watch – or upload your own.														Powerful analysis				Add tools for statistical and geospatial analyses that run right in your browser.														Proven platform				My Forest Atlas is built on ESRI’s easy-to-use ArcGIS Online mapping platform.														Broad reach				Share your maps with integrated social media tools, or add it to the map gallery.												Start Building Your Map		Here’s your 1-2-3 guide on getting started.															  													1							Watch the tutorial videos							These step-by-step guides will teach you how to set up an ArcGIS Online user account, produce a basic interactive map, and share your map online.										  				  													2							Create a map							Add data layers to the map canvas, and start styling. All of your progress will be saved to your account, so you can work at your own pace.										  				  													3							Share your forest atlas							Use integrated social media tools to share your interactive map with your networks, export the map as a static image, or submit it into the map gallery.										  															Get started							Featured Maps		A hand-picked selection of GFW maps and applications built by our user community. Imagine your map here!														                                                                                            						  						  					  																				Atlas 1														  							  							                                                          						  						  					  																				Atlas 2														  							  							                                                                                                      						  						  					  																				Atlas 3														  							  							                                                                                						  						  					  																				Atlas 4														  							  							                                                          						  						  					  																				Atlas 5														  							  							                                                          						  						  					  																				Atlas 6														  							  							                                                                                						  						  					  																				Atlas 7														  							  							                                                          						  						  					  																				Atlas 8														  							  							                                    						  						  					  																				Atlas 9														  							  							                                    						  						  					  																				Atlas 10														  							  							                        															Submit your map		View all							Tutorials		Just getting started?
